facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1080 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1080 of 1965.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shelat, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shelat, J.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate granted by Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate granted by the Punjab High Court raises the following question

facts.text: Respondent is a partnership firm registered under the Punjab General Sales Tax Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a partnership firm registered under the Act and was at the material time carrying on business

facts.text: Respondent carried on business in vegetable ghee, sugar and other commodities.

anchor.surface_text: in vegetable ghee, sugar and other companymodities. The assessment year in question companymenced

facts.text: Assessment year commenced April 1, 1955 and ended March 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment year in question companymenced from April 1, 1955 and. ended on March 31, 1956.

facts.text: Dealer furnished quarterly returns: April-June 1954 on October 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The dealer furnished four quarterly returns as required by the Rules framed under the Act. viz,., for the period April to June, 1954 on October 1, 1954

facts.text: Dealer furnished quarterly returns: July-September 1954 on December 16, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: July to September, 1954 on December 16, 1954 October to December, 1954 on March 12, 1955

facts.text: Dealer furnished quarterly returns: October-December 1954 on March 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: October to December, 1954 on March 12, 1955 and for January to March, 1955 on June 16, 1956.

facts.text: Dealer furnished quarterly returns: January-March 1955 on June 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and for January to March, 1955 on June 16, 1956. Though these returns were number filed within 30 days

facts.text: Returns filed after 30 days expiry of quarters, no objection by Assessing Authority.

anchor.surface_text: Though these returns were number filed within 30 days after expiry of each of the quarters as required by the Rules, numberobjection was taken

facts.text: Firm deposited Rs. 10,649-4-0 at time of filing returns.

anchor.surface_text: The firm deposited three sums at the time of filing the returns aggregating to Rs. 10,649-4-0.

facts.text: Firm paid further Rs. 14,477 on basis of returns.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, it paid a further sum of Rs. 14,477 on the basis of those returns.

facts.text: Assessing Authority issued notice under S. 11(2) in form S.T. XIV, served on January 11, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Not satisfied with these returns, the Assessing Authority issued a numberice under S. 1 1  2  in form S.T. XIV which is a companyprehensive form and which admittedly was served on the dealer on January 11, 1957,

facts.text: Notice served before three years from dates for filing returns: first July 30, 1954, last April 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: i.e before three years expired from each of the respective dates for filing of the said returns. This is clear from the fact that the date for filing the first return would be July 30, 1954

facts.text: Assessing Authority examined Tara Chand, a partner, on July 5, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1960, the Assessing Authority examined Tara Chand, a partner in the firm but did number finalise the assessment order on that day

facts.text: Assessment order passed on August 11, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: as he wanted to make further enquiries and passed the assessment order impugned in this appeal on August 11, 1960.

facts.text: Assessing Authority disbelieved accounts produced by Tara Chand.

anchor.surface_text: The Assessing Authority disbelieved the accounts produced by Tara Chand and added sales of Rs. 4,00,000

facts.text: Added sales of Rs. 4,00,000 to gross turnover.

anchor.surface_text: and added sales of Rs. 4,00,000 in the gross turnover shown in the returns and assessed the firm on the turnover of Rs. 16,92,148-1-0

facts.text: Assessed on turnover of Rs. 16,92,148-1-0 to tax of Rs. 33,127-1-6.

anchor.surface_text: assessed the firm on the turnover of Rs. 16,92,148-1-0 to a tax of Rs. 33,127-1-6.

facts.text: After credits, balance of Rs. 8,000 payable by firm.

anchor.surface_text: After giving credit of the said two sums deposited by the dealer the balance of Rs. 8,000 and odd remained payable by the firm.

facts.text: Firm filed writ petition in High Court challenging assessment as time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: The firm filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging the validity of the assessment order on the ground that as it was made after three years

facts.text: High Court held assessment order under S.11(4), time-barred, without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court following its earlier decision in Mis. Rameshwar Lai Sarup Chand v. The Excise and Taxation Officer 1 , held that the order was an assessment

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 1  provides that if the Assessing Authority is satisfied without requiring the presence of the registered dealer or the production by him of any evidence that the returns furnished in respect of any period are correct and complete, he shall assess the amount of tax due from the dealer on the basis of such returns.

concepts.interpretation: Assessment on basis of returns if satisfied, no further action needed.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  6  deals with a case where a dealer has failed to apply for registration, in which case the Assessing Authority is empowered within the prescribed period to assess such a dealer to the best of his judgment. Since the firm in the instant case was duly registered, the question of application of sub-section  6  does not arise.

concepts.interpretation: Best judgment for unregistered dealers; not applicable here.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 20 of the Punjab General Sales Tax Rules, 1949 provides that every registered dealer, other than those referred to in rules 17, 18 and 19 with whom we are not presently concerned  shall furnish returns quarterly within 30 days from the expiry of each quarter.

concepts.interpretation: Quarterly returns within 30 days of quarter end.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 25 provides that all returns which are required to be furnished under these rules,  1  1963 P.L.R. 768. shall be signed by the registered dealer or his agent and shall be sent to the appropriate Assessing Authority together with the Treasury or the Bank receipt as proof of the payment of the tax due.

concepts.unlisted_description: Signing and payment proof with returns.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 40 provides that a dealer and his partner or partners shall be jointly and severally responsible for payment of the tax, and that every dealer liable to pay the tax shall pay it quarterly unless directed otherwise by the appropriate Assessing Authority.

concepts.unlisted_label: Rule 40 Punjab General Sales Tax Rules 1949

anchor.surface_text: Rule 32 provides that every assessment order shall be recorded in writing and, where the Assessing Authority determines the turnover of a dealer at a figure different from that shown in the return submitted under the provisions of these rules, the order shall state briefly the reasons therefore.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons which we shall presently set out, the question whether the assessment order was passed under s. 11 3 or s. 11 4 or 5 does not need any answer as it makes no difference so far as this case is concerned whether it was made under one or the other sub-section.

arguments.claim: Under s.11(4), limitation period for best judgment is three years after expiry of the period (quarters) for returns; notice after that futile

anchor.surface_text: The question that falls for determination is whether it was one under sub-section 3 or sub-section 4 , is it one which can be said to be time barred? So far as sub-section 4 is concerned the question as to when an assessment order thereunder becomes bar-red arose in Madan Lal Arora v. Excise and Taxation Officer, Amritsar 1 .

arguments.claim: Assessment proceedings commence when registered dealer furnishes return or notice issued under s.11(2); finalisation after limitation ok if initiated timely
Here, notice under s.11(2) dated Jan 11, 1957 within time from return due dates; dealer appeared, produced accounts, enquiry held; proceedings commenced timely

holdings.text: The question whether the assessment order was passed under s. 11(3) or s. 11(4) or (5) does not need any answer as it makes no difference so far as this case is concerned whether it was made under one or the other sub-section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation analysis same regardless of subsection as proceedings timely initiated under either.

holdings.text: The mere fact that the Assessing Authority mentioned that he made the order on the best judgement basis cannot be conclusive, for, by merely calling it as the best judgment assessment, the order does not become one.

anchor.surface_text: However, the mere fact that the Assessing Authority mentioned that he made the order on the best judgement. basis cannot be companyclusive, for, by merely calling it as the best judgment assessment, the order does number become one.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of order determined by facts and compliance with statutory conditions, not mere labeling.

holdings.text: None of the conditions precedent under sub-sections 4, 5 and 6 existed in the present case and therefore the impugned order cannot be said to be either under sub-section 4 or sub-section 5 or sub-section 6.

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie, numbere of these companyditions existed in the present case and therefore though the Assessing Authority states that he had to assess the firm to the best of his judgment, the impugned order cannot be said to be either under sub-section  4  or sub-section  5  or sub-section  6 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dealer furnished returns and complied with notice under s.11(2); no failure triggering best judgment provisions.

holdings.text: Assessment proceedings commence in the case of a registered dealer either when he furnishes a return or when a notice is issued to him under s.11(2), and if such proceedings are taken within the prescribed time though the assessment is finalised subsequently even after the expiry of the prescribed period, no question of limitation would arise.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Ghanshyam Das v. Regional Assistant Commissioner; proceedings pending from initiation until final order.

holdings.text: In the instant case, the assessment proceedings commenced either when the respondent firm filed the returns or in any event from the date of the notice dated January 11, 1957, both within prescribed time; hence the assessment order is not time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case the dealer filed returns. Though they were led after the expiry of 30 days from the relevant date, they were number rejected by the department on that ground. In fact the numberice dated January 11, 1957 issued under s. 11  2 was on the footing that returns were filed, but the Assessing Authority was number satisfied with them and desired evidence to establish that the returns were full and companyplete.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Returns filed (late but accepted), notice under s.11(2) within 3 years of due dates, dealer complied, enquiry held per Ghanshyam Das.

holdings.text: The decisions of the Punjab High Court in Rameshwar Lal Sarup Chand and Jagat Ram Om Parkash are not applicable as the question of proceedings having commenced within time and remaining pending was not considered therein.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance, however, was placed on two decisions of the High Court of Punjab M s. Rameshwar Lal Sarup Chand v. Excise and Taxation Officer 2 and Jagat Ram Om Parkash v. Excise and Taxation Officer, Assessing Authority, Amritsar 3 . Neither of these decisions would be of assistance as the question which was canvassed in Ghanshyam Dass case  1  regarding assessment proceedings having companymenced within time and then remaining pending did number companye up for companysideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished for not addressing timely commencement and pendency of proceedings as in Ghanshyam Das.

precedents.cited_proposition: three years limitation under s.11(4) counted from expiry of the period (quarter) for which returns furnished; notice issued after three years is futile

anchor.surface_text: The question as to the legal effect of such a notice was considered in Ghanshyam Das v. Regional Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax, Nagpur 1 . The points which fell for determination there were  1  when can a proceeding be said to commence

precedents.case_name: Ghanshyam Das v. Regional Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax, Nagpur
precedents.cited_proposition: assessment proceedings commence when return filed or notice under s.11(2) issued; if commenced within limitation period, final order after expiry not time-barred
precedents.cited_holding: assessment proceedings under the Act must be held to be pending from the time they are initiated until they are terminated by a final order of assessment... no question of limitation would arise where such proceedings are taken before the expiry of the prescribed period though an assessment order is finalised after the expiry
